Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Donor-acceptor-acceptor Homo-Nazarov cyclizations for facile access into functionalized six-membered ring systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this CAREER award, the Chemical Synthesis program of the Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Professor Stefan France of Georgia Institute of Technology. Professor France will develop methodology for the synthesis of six-membered carbocyclic and heterocyclic frameworks based on Lewis acid-catalyzed homo-Nazarov cyclizations of donor-acceptor-acceptor cyclopropanes. Specific aims include: 1) the use of novel donor-acceptor-acceptor cyclopropane substrates; 2) the use of other functionalizable acceptor groups; 3) the achievement of asymmetric induction through chirality transfer or asymmetric catalysis; 4) the exploitation of carbocation rearrangements as a synthetic tool; and 5) their applications toward the synthesis of complex molecules.

Professor France will also initiate three educational projects that interweave research and teaching. The first project involves an outreach program at a local high school that promotes active learning through the design and implementation of the case study method in science. The second project involves redesigning the undergraduate introductory organic chemistry course in order to eliminate the traditional lecture model. The third project is focused on increasing the representation of underrepresented minorities in chemistry through a combination of recruiting efforts and mentoring activities. Besides these educational impacts, this work could lead to more efficient methods for the preparation of complex organic molecules. Therefore, it will have an impact on any area in which the synthesis of molecules is needed, such as the pharmaceutical, chemical, agricultural industry, and biological and chemical research activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: To date, a total of 16 publications, 18 presentations (at regional and national ACS conferences), and 6 theses (5 graduate, 1 undergraduate) have been produced that directly relate to the overall intellectual merit of the program. The France lab has focused its method development efforts on catalytic, formal homo-Nazarov and homo-Nazarov-type ring-opening cyclization chemistries due to the broad substrate scope and modularity in generating diverse molecular architectures. These methods can then be applied in natural products chemistry, materoials science, medicinal chemistry, and chemical biology. Highlights include:

  • Pioneered the development/advancement of N-acryloyl indoles (N-AIs) and N-acryloyl pyrroles (N-APs) as simple, readily accessible and highly modular chemical building blocks
  • Developed a diastereoselective, Lewis acid-catalyzed intramolecular Friedel-Crafts reaction that efficiently generates functionalized 1H-pyrrolo-[1,2-a]indole-3(2H)-ones in high yields with high diastereoselectivities
  • Disclosed six-step total synthesis of deethyleburnaminone, a naturally-occurring alkaloid
  • Developed a highly modular approach to the pyrrolo[3,2,1-ij]quinoline skeleton that outpaces literature examples
  • Developed a novel Lewis acid catalyzed cycloisomerization of heteroaryl cyclopropene-3,3- dicarbonyl compounds to functionalized benzo-fused heteroaromatics and heterobiaryls
  • Contributed a tutorial review on the intramolecular ring-opening cyclizations of donor-acceptor cyclopropanes that has been cited >140 times since its publication in 2014
  • Disclosed a Lewis acid-catalyzed, formal homo-Nazarov-type cyclization of alkylidene cyclopropane-1,1-ketoesters to form functionalized arenes and heteroarenes
  • Developed a diastereoselective Lewis acid catalyzed approach to azepino[1,2-a]indoles that represents the most efficient route published to date
  • Demonstrated the first examples of Lewis acid catalyzed intramolecular ring-opening cyclizations of donor-acceptor cyclobutanes.
  • Developed a chemodivergent interrupted formal homo-Nazarov cyclization using allylsilanes as nucleophiles for trapping the six-membered oxyallyl cation intermediate derived from donor-acceptor cyclopropanes
  • Developed a tandem, bicatalytic continuous flow cyclopropanation-homo-Nazarov-type ring-opening cyclization to form hydropyrido[1,2-a]indoles that provided high conversions (up to 97%) with product throughputs on the order of 3-5 g h-1.
  • Contributed a review on the catalytic, formal homo-Nazarov cyclization as a template for diversity-oriented synthesis.
  • Developed a Lewis acid-catalyzed, formal homo-Nazarov cyclization toward functionalized 5,6,7,8-tetrahydroindolizines
  • Developed a catalytic, cascade ring-opening benzannulation of 2,3-dihydrofuran-O,O- and N,O- acetals
  • Developed a catalytic, interrupted formal homo-Nazarov cyclization using arenes and to form functionalized a-(hetero)arylcyclohexanones
  • Developed a calcium-catalyzed, dehydrative, ring-opening cyclization of cyclopropyl carbinols derived from donor-acceptor cyclopropanes

Broader Impacts: Graduate Research and Mentorship: This program has significantly contributed to five graduate theses (Drs. D. V. Patil, L. H. Phun, J. Aponte-Guzman, M. A. Cavitt, and R. Shenje). Undergraduate Research: As part of the Award, a summer REU component was one of the primary educational goals.  Through partnership with the School of Chemistry and Biochemistry REU Program (NSF 1156657), at least one female and/or minority student has been mentored every summer of the award (five to date).  I have included undergraduate researchers from my lab as authors on research papers. Former REU students, Elayna Tillman and Katherine Francois, are each contributing authors on two separate manuscripts. Two other former REUs were awarded 2012 NSF Graduate Research Fellowships (one Hispanic male and one Hispanic female). My lab also mentored a total of 8 GaTech undergraduates and two international exchange students to work on the program. These former undergrads are currently enrolled in graduate programs (med school, Ph.D, Pharm. D., etc.) or working as teachers, researchers at government labs, or in other STEM-related professions. Undergraduate Paul Grzybowski, a co-author on two manuscripts, graduated as part of the Georgia Tech undergraduate thesis program and is currently working as an intern at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). As a testament to my efforts in promoting undergraduate research, I was awarded the 2015 Georgia Tech Outstanding Undergraduate Mentor Award. Broadening Participation/Recruiting: I am actively involved in the School of Chemistry and Biochemistry's recruitment efforts, both at the graduate and undergraduate levels, through activities during the recruitment weekends. I have also been an active participant in Georgia Tech’s FOCUS recruiting program for minority students, postdocs and faculty. I have served as a speaker at several diversity-focused symposia, minority-serving institutions, and minority-serving national conferences. I was the keynote speaker at the 2013 December meeting of the Cincinnati ACS, which was co-sponsored with the city-wide NOBBChE Chapter. During this meeting, I ran a STEM Career panel for ~20-25 minority freshman and sophomores.  From 2011-2012, I hosted a local high school African-American high school student, Antron Spooner, in my lab to perform research. Antron graduated in Spring 2012 and is currently enrolled at Cornell University where he is majoring in biology and chemistry. As a testament to my commitment to Outreach, I was awarded the 2014 Georgia Tech Faculty Award for Academic Outreach.


Last Modified: 11/22/2016
Modified by: Stefan A France
